hedline.hl1: 'Hot Hands' Strategy Beats Buy and Hold

abstract.p: Study published in Journal of Financial Planning reveals that returns from 'hot hands' investing--frequent trades of recently outstanding stocks--outperforms conservative buy and hold investing (S)

block.p: Mutual fund investors are typically warned not to follow the ''hot hands'' -- that is, to chase recent outstanding performance with frequent trades. The better strategy, they are told, is to buy fund shares and hold them long term. But a recent study turns that advice on its head.

Thomas J. Zwirlein and Venkateshwar K. The study was published in the August 2000 issue of the Journal of Financial Planning.

Mutual fund investors are typically warned not to follow the ''hot hands'' -- that is, to chase recent outstanding performance with frequent trades. The better strategy, they are told, is to buy fund shares and hold them long term. But a recent study turns that advice on its head.

Thomas J. Zwirlein and Venkateshwar K. Reddy, associate professors of finance at the University of Colorado in Colorado Springs, concluded that a follow-the-winner approach works better than a buy-and-hold approach in I.R.A.'s, 401(k) plans and other tax-favored accounts. The study was published in the August 2000 issue of the Journal of Financial Planning.

The study, which used Morningstar data covering January 1977 to December 1992, simulated investing $600 monthly in one or more of six types of mutual funds: aggressive growth, growth, growth and income, small company, international and balanced.

In the study, the researchers compared the returns and risk for three investing strategies. The first was a buy-and-hold approach, in which they put $100 into each type of fund every month. The second was the low-cost method -- investing the entire $600 in the poorest-performing category, as some investors do to get more shares. The third was a hot-hands strategy, in which they put the $600 into the best-performing category, along with the entire amount already invested; the portfolio was updated quarterly.
The ''hot hands'' brought the 15-year total to $489,023, compared with $345,838 for the buy-and-hold approach and $320,335 for the low-cost method.

The hot-hands strategy has higher risk, the authors noted, and may not be suitable for all investors. Moreover, it works best in tax-deferred accounts because the frequent trades could result in taxable gains in a regular account.
